heading: Story Form
text: Story Form is a representation of a BDD story. It is divided into 3 parts: Name, Story and Scenarios.

heading: Story Name
text: Name, together with the directory path, forms the unique identification of the BDD story.

heading: Expand Panels
text: Click the button to expand panels. Click next when finished to continue with the tour.

heading: Story Panel
text: Story is divided into 5 sections. None of the sections is mandatory.

heading: Story Description
text: This free-text field is for informational purposes only. It can be used as a way to provide any type of information not already covered with other sections (i.e. narrative, scenarios, etc). In cases where narrative is not appropriate, description can be used as an alternative.

heading: Story Narrative
text:
Narrative is equivalent to a user story. The purpose of narrative is to capture initial idea or requirement and initiate conversation that will result in one or more scenarios. It consists of 3 fields:
  • In order to [ACCOMPLISH SOMETHING]
  • As a [USER OR ROLE THAT NEEDS THE NEW FEATURE]
  • I want to [DO SOMETHING]

heading: Story Lifecycle
text: Lifecycle is split into two sub-sections: Before and After. Each can define a set of steps that are run before or after each scenario. Lifecycle is very useful when all scenarios of one BDD story start or end with the same set of steps.

heading: Scenarios
text: Click the button to expand this scenario. Click next when finished to continue with the tour.

heading: Scenarios
text: Each BDD story has at least one scenario. Each of the scenarios is separated into 3 sections: Meta, Steps and Examples.

heading: Scenario Steps
text: Scenario steps are the heart and soul of BDD stories. They describe preconditions (Given), actions (When) and expected outcomes (Then).

heading: Add Elements
text: Metas, given stories, lifecycle steps, steps and scenarios can be added (), moved (), and removed ()

heading: Auto-complete
text: All step fields (within lifecycle or scenarios) support the auto-complete feature. Start writing the word that identifies some step and the GUI will display the list of candidates. Once the desired step is found, space of enter key will add it to the corresponding field.

heading: Story Operations
text: Following story operations are allowed: save, revert changes, delete and rename.

heading: Save Story
text: If the BDD story form is valid, data can be permanently saved on the server. In case of a new story, new file is created. Otherwise, the contents of the existing story are overwritten with the modified version. To save the story, click the "Save" button. If saving is not allowed (i.e. invalid story), the button is disabled.

heading: Revert Story
text: Any change made to the BDD story can be reverted to the version created on the last save. To revert the BDD story, click the "Revert Changes" button. This operation cannot be undone. If there were no changes in the BDD story, the button is disabled.

heading: Delete Story
text: Any BDD story can be deleted. This operation cannot be undone. If the BDD story was not previously saved in the server, the button is disabled.

heading: Rename Story
text: Any BDD story can be renamed by changing the name and saving changes.

heading: Run Story
text: This button brings up the dialog with parameters required to run the story (Single Story Runner). More information can be found in the tour available inside the dialog.

heading: Single Story Runner
text:
Single Story Runner is commonly used during the specification and development of some story. After scenarios are written, developers should use the BDD in the TDD fashion:
  • Run scenarios and confirm that at least one has failed or has pending steps
  • Implement the first scenario that failed or has pending steps
  • Run scenarios and confirm that the previous scenario that failed or had pending steps is working
  • Refactor
  • Repeat
